items.text: A comprehensive IT management framework (policies, processes, structures) is formally documented in writing.
The IT management framework covers the main dimensions: strategy, risks, security, projects, operations.
The IT management framework is known and used by key IT managers.
IT policies are formally approved by management (executive committee, IT committee, etc.).
IT policies are communicated to teams through structured channels (intranet, email, training).
Employees can easily access up-to-date IT policies (document repository, portal).
Key IT processes are described (diagrams, process sheets, procedures).
Process descriptions are kept up to date in case of significant changes.
Teams know the processes to follow for their activities (support, projects, changes, etc.).
Performance indicators are defined for the IT management system (e.g., compliance, timeline, quality).
Indicators are monitored regularly and are the subject of reports.
Indicator results lead to decisions or improvement actions for the IT management system.
Key IT management roles (CIO, domain managers, etc.) are formalized in role or job descriptions.
Decision-making and escalation responsibilities are clearly defined for each IT role.
Relevant stakeholders are informed of their responsibilities and actually assume them.
The IT management system explicitly references recognized frameworks (COBIT, ITIL, ISO, etc.).
Internal IT practices are periodically compared to best practices from these frameworks.
Some IT processes have been designed or adjusted based on these frameworks.
Formal reviews of the IT management system are planned (at least annually).
IT management system review reports are documented and distributed to stakeholders.
Review conclusions are integrated into IT improvement plans.
Gaps identified during IT management system reviews are recorded with their root causes.
Action plans are defined, with owners and deadlines, to correct these gaps.
Action plan monitoring is ensured and gaps are reclassified once addressed.
A formal IT strategy document (or equivalent) exists and covers a multi-year horizon.
Senior management or the executive committee has validated the IT strategy.
The IT strategy defines clear and measurable objectives for the organization.
IT strategy objectives are explicitly aligned with business strategic objectives.
Business stakeholders participated in the development or validation of the IT strategy.
Major IT projects and initiatives are directly linked to business objectives.
The IT strategy includes a vision for the organization's digital transformation.
Technological innovation (data, cloud, AI, etc.) is considered as a strategic lever.
Identified digital opportunities are translated into concrete initiatives or programs.
The IT strategy is presented and explained to business managers.
IT managers communicate the strategy to their teams (meetings, materials, intranet).
IT employees know the main directions of the IT strategy.
IT roadmaps (or strategic action plans) are defined with dated milestones.
Priorities of IT actions or projects are clearly ranked in the roadmap.
IT roadmaps are reviewed periodically and adjusted if necessary.
The IT strategy is reviewed regularly (for example, annually).
Internal changes (organization, business priorities) are taken into account during reviews.
External changes (regulation, market, technologies) are also integrated into strategic thinking.
Risks related to technological choices and digital transformation are identified in the IT strategy.
IT opportunities (new services, new markets) are analyzed at the strategic level.
Strategic IT trade-offs take into account a risk/opportunity balance.
Business representatives participate in forums where IT strategy is discussed.
Business units are consulted to express their needs and expectations during IT strategy development.
Business feedback on IT strategy is taken into account in adjustments.
A formal enterprise architecture approach is defined (framework, principles, roles).
The architecture covers at minimum processes, data, applications, and technologies.
An enterprise architecture manager or team is identified.
Urbanization or architecture repositories (maps, models, standards) are documented.
These repositories are regularly updated to reflect the current architecture.
The repositories are accessible and used by project and technical teams.
IT projects must obtain an architecture review (or equivalent) before key decisions.
Any deviations from architecture principles are documented and justified.
Decisions not to comply with architecture are validated at an appropriate level.
A mapping of existing applications is maintained.
The main data flows between applications are documented.
The mapping is used to analyze impacts of changes or rationalization of the IS.
Decisions to acquire or develop solutions take into account the target architecture.
Project committees must demonstrate their consistency with architecture principles.
The target architecture is used as a criterion in solution option studies.
Enterprise architecture is subject to regular reviews (e.g., annual).
Major technological developments (cloud, data, etc.) are integrated into architecture thinking.
Major business changes (new products, acquisitions) are taken into account in the architecture.
Gaps between target architecture and current architecture are identified and mapped.
Gap reduction plans (projects, initiatives) are defined.
Priority gaps are specifically tracked in IT roadmaps.
Architecture committees (or equivalent forums) examine structural solution choices.
Architecture decisions (technologies, integration, cloud) are recorded and tracked.
Architecture committee members understand the business issues associated with technical decisions.
A formal IT innovation management process or framework is defined.
The innovation approach stages (idea, evaluation, experimentation, industrialization) are described.
Roles and responsibilities for driving IT innovation are identified.
A channel (tool, suggestion box, process) allows users and internal teams to propose ideas.
Submitted ideas are evaluated and receive feedback (acceptance, rejection, pending).
Business units are encouraged to contribute to IT innovation (workshops, challenges, hackathons).
Evaluation criteria for innovation ideas are defined (value, risk, feasibility, strategic alignment).
Prioritization decisions for innovation initiatives are based on these criteria.
Decisions to launch, defer, or abandon an idea are tracked and justified.
Experiments (POC, pilots) are framed by a clear and measurable objective.
Risks associated with experiments (technical, security, reputation) are assessed and limited.
Success/stop criteria are defined before launching each experiment.
Results of innovation projects (successes or failures) are formally evaluated.
Lessons learned from innovation initiatives are documented.
Best practices or mistakes to avoid are shared with relevant teams.
Innovation projects are aligned with the company's strategic axes.
Innovation vs. other project trade-offs take strategic priorities into account.
Business sponsors validate the consistency of innovation projects with their objectives.
A budget dedicated to IT innovation (or envelope) is identified.
Time is allocated to teams to contribute to innovation initiatives.
Skills necessary for innovation (UX, data, cloud, etc.) are available or developed.
Technological, security, and regulatory risks related to innovations are assessed upfront.
Risk/security managers are involved in evaluating sensitive innovation projects.
Innovations presenting high risk are subject to enhanced controls or mitigation measures.
A consolidated portfolio of IT projects is maintained (global view).
Recurring IT services (run) are also visible in a global portfolio view.
Portfolio information (status, priorities, resources) is regularly updated.
Project requests follow a formalized submission process (file, form, tool).
A committee or forum decides on the selection/rejection of project requests.
Selection criteria are known (value, risks, costs, strategic alignment).
Portfolio prioritization criteria are defined (benefits, risks, costs, resources).
Prioritization decisions are based on these criteria (not solely on perceived urgency).
Prioritization is reviewed periodically according to context evolution.
The IT portfolio is presented and reviewed regularly by management or a dedicated committee.
Portfolio arbitration decisions (launch, stop, delay) are documented.
Portfolio reviews enable detection of projects in difficulty and decision on actions.
Projects in difficulty (delays, cost overruns, quality issues) are identified using objective criteria.
Formal decisions are made for these projects (recovery plan, re-scoping, termination).
Decisions are communicated to relevant stakeholders.
The portfolio is aligned with the company's strategic priorities (overall view).
Low-value or off-strategy projects are challenged.
The organization's capacities (resources, budget) are taken into account in portfolio size.
Load on critical resources is visible in portfolio tools or reports.
Priority conflicts on these resources are arbitrated at portfolio level.
Decisions are made to limit overload on certain teams or key profiles.
Project progress information (costs, timelines, risks) is updated in the portfolio.
Portfolio data is considered reliable by management.
Portfolio reports are produced at a frequency appropriate for decision-making.
A formal IT budgeting process is defined and aligned with the overall budget calendar.
The different components of the IT budget (projects, run, investments, OPEX) are identified.
Business units are involved in IT budget development when relevant.
IT costs are broken down by nature (licenses, maintenance, personnel, etc.).
IT costs are broken down by service or domain (e.g., key applications, infrastructure services).
Cost breakdown enables identification of main expense items.
IT projects have business cases or investment files.
Cost and benefit assumptions are formalized in these business cases.
Business cases are reviewed and validated before budget approval.
Actual project expenses are tracked against approved budgets.
Significant overruns are reported and analyzed.
Budget adjustments are decided and tracked when necessary.
Significant budget variances (projects or run) are identified in reports.
Causes of these variances are analyzed (estimation errors, scope, risks, etc.).
Lessons learned are taken into account in subsequent budgeting cycles.
IT costs are explained to business units in an understandable manner (reports, presentations).
A chargeback or showback mechanism exists where applicable.
Business units understand the main drivers of their IT costs.
IT cost optimization initiatives are identified (rationalization, pooling, cloud, etc.).
These initiatives are managed and tracked (savings targets, progress, results).
Optimization decisions take into account impacts on quality and risks.
Financial risks related to IT activities (cost overruns, penalties, contracts, obsolescence) are identified.
These risks are assessed and tracked in a register or appropriate tool.
Mitigation actions are defined for major financial risks.
A specific HR strategy for IT teams is defined (recruitment, retention, skill development).
Medium-term IT resource needs are assessed.
Concrete actions are planned to attract and retain IT talent.
Key necessary skills (technical, functional, security, management) are identified.
A mapping of existing skills in IT teams is available.
Gaps between necessary skills and available skills are analyzed.
A training or IT skill development plan is formalized.
Certification and technical training needs are identified and prioritized.
Completed training actions are tracked and evaluated.
IT job descriptions are formalized and up to date.
Job descriptions reflect responsibilities actually exercised.
Job descriptions are used during recruitment and performance evaluations.
Individual and team objectives are defined for IT employees.
Performance evaluations are conducted regularly.
Results of these evaluations feed into HR decisions (evolution, training, recognition).
Knowledge transfer mechanisms are in place (pair programming, documentation, co-facilitation, etc.).
Critical knowledge does not rely solely on a single person.
Departures or transfers of key people are managed with handover plans.
The turnover rate in IT teams is monitored.
Risks of departure of critical profiles are identified.
Actions are implemented to limit the loss of critical skills (retention, backup, etc.).
IT team workload is monitored to avoid chronic overload.
Working conditions (remote work, tools, environment) are taken into account in team management.
Actions are taken to improve IT team well-being and engagement.
Main business stakeholders are identified for each IT service.
Roles of these stakeholders (sponsor, process owner, key user) are defined.
Contact information for business contacts is kept up to date.
Business relationship managers or business correspondents are designated.
Formal communication channels (committees, regular meetings) with business units are defined.
Business contacts know who to address for their IT topics.
Business needs for IT services are collected in a structured manner (workshops, interviews, surveys).
Business requests are analyzed and prioritized with their participation.
Business feedback on the adequacy of services to their needs is regularly taken into account.
User satisfaction surveys or measurements are regularly conducted.
Satisfaction results are analyzed and shared with IT and business teams.
Improvement plans are defined based on satisfaction results.
Service commitments (SLAs, support levels) are discussed with business units before implementation.
Business units validate the proposed commitments (schedules, timelines, availability).
Commitments are formalized in shared documents (SLAs, service contracts).
Recurring pain points between business and IT are identified (delays, quality, understanding, etc.).
These pain points are subject to concrete action plans (process improvement, communication, tools).
The results of these actions are monitored to verify the reduction of pain points.
Business units are informed in advance of changes impacting services (maintenance, migration, outages).
Communication plans are defined for major changes.
Communicated information is understandable for business users (impact, duration, expected actions).
Regular monitoring committees between IT and business management exist (steering committees, service committees, etc.).
Minutes of these committees are documented and shared.
Decisions made in these forums are effectively implemented.
A formal IT service catalog exists.
The catalog describes services in terms understandable for users (description, recipients, etc.).
The catalog is accessible to users (portal, intranet).
SLAs are defined for critical services (availability, response time, resolution time).
SLAs are accepted by business units and documented.
SLAs serve as the basis for support and production commitments.
Service performance indicators (availability, incidents, response time) are monitored.
Results are regularly reported to IT and business managers.
Deviations or performance degradations lead to analyses and actions.
SLAs are reviewed periodically with business units.
SLAs are adjusted when business needs or technical capabilities evolve.
SLA reviews are tracked and changes are formalized.
Significant deviations from SLAs are identified.
The causes of these deviations are analyzed (capacity, incidents, organization).
Improvement plans are defined to reduce these deviations.
Internal OLAs are defined between IT teams to support SLAs (operations, network, security, etc.).
OLAs detail the responsibilities and intervention timelines for each team.
OLA compliance is monitored and discussed between internal teams.
Users have clear channels to report incidents or requests (portal, phone, email).
Channels are communicated and easily accessible.
Requests are recorded and tracked until their resolution.
IT service costs are documented and, where applicable, communicated to business units.
Billing or chargeback mechanisms are transparent.
Business units understand the cost composition of their main services.
An IT supplier management policy is formalized.
This policy covers the supplier lifecycle (selection, contracting, monitoring, exit).
Relevant teams know the principles of this policy.
Supplier selection criteria are defined (quality, costs, security, compliance, location, etc.).
Tenders or consultations integrate these criteria into their evaluation grids.
Selection decisions are justified against these criteria.
IT contracts include clauses on service levels (SLAs).
Contracts include security and confidentiality clauses appropriate to the context.
Specific regulatory obligations (e.g., data protection) are integrated into contracts.
Supplier performance is monitored through indicators (quality, timelines, availability, etc.).
Regular performance reviews are organized with key suppliers.
Improvement plans are defined in case of insufficient performance.
Risks related to IT suppliers (dependency, security, continuity, location) are identified.
These risks are assessed and integrated into overall IT risk management.
Mitigation measures are in place for critical supplier risks.
Contracts with critical suppliers include continuity or reversibility clauses.
Exit or supplier replacement scenarios are considered.
Failover or continuity capabilities are tested if necessary.
Regulatory requirements (GDPR, regulated sector, etc.) are taken into account when selecting suppliers.
Contracts include specific regulatory compliance clauses.
Supplier compliance with these requirements is reviewed periodically.
Disputes or contractual breaches with suppliers are formalized.
A defined process exists to handle these disputes (escalation levels, mediation, termination).
Decisions made in the context of these disputes are documented and communicated.
A quality policy covering IT activities is formalized.
This policy is communicated to IT teams and relevant business units.
IT quality objectives are defined (e.g., defect rate, user satisfaction).
IT processes include quality control points (reviews, tests, validations).
Quality controls are tracked (minutes, reports, tickets).
Anomalies detected during controls lead to corrections before production deployment.
Recurring incidents or defects are inventoried and analyzed.
Root causes of major defects are investigated.
Recurring causes (processes, tools, skills) are subject to improvement actions.
Continuous improvement plans are defined based on quality results.
These plans include actions, owners, and deadlines.
Monitoring of these plans is performed and results are measured.
Quality requirements (standards, regulations, contracts) applicable to IT are identified.
These requirements are taken into account in the design of processes and solutions.
Teams are informed of quality requirements that concern them.
Internal or external audits evaluate the quality of IT processes and deliverables.
Audit reports are shared with IT managers.
Audit recommendations are subject to monitored action plans.
The quality of project deliverables (specifications, developments, tests) is evaluated according to defined criteria.
Defects detected in testing or production are analyzed by type and origin.
Improvement actions target the most deficient phases or deliverable types.
User feedback on IT service quality is collected (surveys, feedback).
This feedback is analyzed to identify improvement areas.
Actions decided following user feedback are implemented and monitored.
An IT risk management method is defined (steps, deliverables, criteria).
Roles for IT risk management (risk owners, managers) are identified.
Expected deliverables (risk register, treatment plans) are formalized.
Structured workshops are organized to identify IT risks.
Specific analyses (mapping, scenario analyses, risk studies) are conducted.
An IT risk map is produced and used.
IT risks are assessed in probability according to a defined scale.
Risk impacts (financial, operational, reputational, compliance) are assessed with a consistent method.
Assessments are documented in a risk register.
Treatment options are defined for each significant risk (reduction, transfer, acceptance, avoidance).
Treatment plans include actions, owners, and deadlines.
Decisions to accept certain risks are formalized.
The IT risk register is updated regularly.
Progress of treatment plans is monitored (completion rate, delayed actions).
Residual risks after treatment are reassessed.
IT risks are included in the organization's global risk register.
Risk classes and scales used are consistent with those of global risk management.
Global risk committees review major IT risks.
Major incidents (outage, cyberattack, data leak, etc.) are subject to formal lessons learned.
Lessons learned from these incidents lead to updates of the risk register.
Risk treatment actions are adjusted following significant incidents.
Risk appetite for IT is defined by management (acceptable risk level).
Tolerance thresholds are set for certain major IT risks (e.g., availability, security).
These thresholds guide treatment decisions and risk prioritization.
An information security policy is defined and approved by management.
The policy covers the main dimensions (confidentiality, integrity, availability, compliance).
The policy is communicated to employees and accessible.
Information security risks are assessed regularly through a structured approach.
Security risks are recorded in a register or appropriate tool.
Identified security risks feed into security plans (projects, technical measures, organizational measures).
Technical security measures are deployed (access control, encryption, antivirus, firewall, etc.).
Organizational measures are in place (charters, procedures, segregation of duties).
Measures are proportionate to identified risks.
Security awareness campaigns are regularly organized (phishing, passwords, etc.).
New hires are sensitized to security during their onboarding.
Awareness is adapted to different profiles (users, administrators, managers).
Security incident management procedures are defined (detection, alert, treatment, recovery).
These procedures are known to relevant teams (SOC, support, operations, etc.).
Procedures are tested periodically (crisis management exercises, simulations).
Regulatory requirements for security and data protection are identified (e.g., GDPR).
Compliance with these requirements is assessed regularly (reviews, audits).
Compliance gaps are subject to monitored action plans.
Privileged accounts (administrators, sensitive access) are inventoried.
Access to these accounts is controlled (password management, vault, bastion, etc.).
Rights and usage of privileged accounts are reviewed periodically.
Security tests are performed (intrusion tests, vulnerability scans).
The results of these tests are analyzed and prioritized.
Identified vulnerabilities are subject to monitored remediation plans.
An I&T governance framework (principles, policies, bodies, roles) is formally documented.
This I&T governance framework is approved by the appropriate management bodies (board, steering committee, I&T governance committee).
The I&T governance framework covers key domains: value, risks, resources, compliance, performance.
I&T governance roles and responsibilities (process owners, committees, I&T management, business functions) are formalized.
A responsibility matrix (RACI type or equivalent) exists for the main I&T governance decisions.
The concerned stakeholders know their governance roles (decide, validate, be consulted, be informed).
Applicable regulatory and normative requirements (GDPR, sectoral regulations, ISO standards, etc.) are identified for I&T.
These requirements are integrated into the I&T governance framework (policies, procedures, controls).
Compliance with these requirements is regularly reviewed by the I&T governance bodies.
Governance decision mechanisms (committees, bodies, validation circuits) are defined and documented.
Escalation rules exist for sensitive subjects (major risks, critical incidents, priority arbitration).
Decisions made in the I&T governance committee are tracked (minutes, action plans).
The I&T governance framework is aligned with the organization's global governance framework.
Interactions between I&T governance and other bodies (risks, audit, finance, business functions) are defined.
I&T representatives participate in global governance bodies when relevant.
Periodic reviews of the I&T governance framework are planned (at least annually).
These reviews take into account changes in context (strategy, organization, technology, regulation).
The conclusions of the reviews lead to decisions to adjust the governance framework.
The I&T governance framework is communicated to key stakeholders (management, business functions, I&T).
Communication materials (charters, guides, intranet, training) are available and up-to-date.
Governance stakeholders receive, if necessary, specific awareness or training for their roles.
Audits or maturity assessments of I&T governance are carried out periodically.
Recommendations from these assessments are prioritized and integrated into improvement plans.
The progress of I&T governance is monitored through indicators or maturity objectives.
Major I&T projects and programs have formalized business cases.
Expected benefits (financial and non-financial) are explicitly described in these business cases.
Key assumptions related to benefits (volumes, productivity gains, quality improvement, etc.) are documented.
Value and benefit indicators are defined for I&T investments (KPIs).
Target objectives are set for these indicators (success thresholds, ROI, adoption, satisfaction).
Measurement methods (data source, frequency, responsible party) are defined.
Realized benefits are tracked after solutions are put into production (post-project monitoring).
The results of benefit realization are compared to the initial expected benefits.
Significant deviations (benefits not achieved or exceeded) are subject to analysis and decisions.
IT and business responsibilities for achieving benefits are clearly assigned.
Benefit owners (business sponsors) are identified for the main projects.
Governance committees monitor the contribution of each I&T initiative to value creation.
Post-implementation reviews (PIR or equivalent) are carried out for major I&T projects.
These reviews assess benefit realization, actual costs, risks, and lessons learned.
Lessons learned from these reviews feed into value and project management practices.
Decisions to launch, continue, or stop I&T initiatives take into account whether value is being created.
Projects with low value contribution or a poor benefit/cost ratio are challenged.
Portfolio arbitrations systematically include a consolidated view of benefits.
Non-financial benefits (customer satisfaction, quality, compliance, image) are also taken into account.
These non-financial benefits are measured and reported when relevant.
Governance committees examine the balance between financial and non-financial benefits.
I&T value management practices are periodically reviewed (methods, indicators, roles).
Identified improvements (better definition of benefits, reinforced monitoring, tooling) are implemented.
The maturity of I&T value management progresses over time (lessons learned, benchmarking).
An I&T risk management policy is formalized and approved by management.
This policy is aligned with the organization's global risk management framework.
The policy specifies the objectives, roles, responsibilities, and principles of I&T risk management.
An I&T risk register (strategic, operational, cyber, compliance) is maintained.
I&T risks are identified in a structured manner (workshops, analyses, incident feedback, audits).
Major risks are clearly distinguished from lower-level risks.
I&T risks are assessed according to probability and impact criteria consistent with the global risk framework.
Risk appetite and tolerance thresholds specific to I&T are defined and validated.
Risks exceeding tolerance thresholds are identified and escalated to governance bodies.
Treatment plans are defined for significant I&T risks (reduction, transfer, acceptance, avoidance).
Treatment plans specify the actions, responsible parties, deadlines, and necessary resources.
Decisions to accept certain risks are formalized and validated at the appropriate hierarchical level.
Decisions regarding I&T projects and investments take into account the analysis of corresponding risks.
Major I&T risks are presented to governance committees for arbitration.
Decisions to continue, redirect, or stop initiatives integrate the risk dimension.
I&T risk dashboards or maps are produced for governance bodies.
Risk evolution trends (improvement, degradation) are monitored and commented upon.
Governance decisions take into account this consolidated risk information.
Major incidents (cyber, unavailability, data breaches) result in formalized lessons learned.
Lessons learned from incidents are integrated into the I&T risk register and analysis.
Risk treatment plans are adapted following significant incidents.
The overall I&T risk profile is periodically reviewed at the governance level (risk committee, I&T committee).
Risk appetite and tolerance thresholds are reassessed based on context changes.
Improvements to the I&T risk management framework are decided and monitored.
A consolidated view of key I&T resources (people, applications, infrastructure, data, suppliers) exists.
Critical resources for business continuity are identified.
Dependencies between resources (e.g., applications and associated infrastructure) are known.
I&T resource allocation decisions are aligned with strategic priorities.
Governance committees arbitrate the distribution of resources among projects, run, and innovation.
Capacity constraints (human, technical, budgetary) are taken into account in decisions.
Indicators of I&T resource load, capacity, and utilization are monitored.
Situations of significant overload or under-utilization are identified.
Rebalancing actions (prioritization, reinforcement, decommissioning) are decided when necessary.
An I&T sourcing strategy (insourcing, outsourcing, cloud, partners) is defined.
Sourcing decisions take into account risks, costs, skills, and supplier dependencies.
Long-term impacts (vendor lock-in, reversibility) are considered in decisions.
Critical and emerging I&T skills are identified (cyber, cloud, data, etc.).
Plans are in place to develop or acquire these skills (training, recruitment, partnership).
Risks related to dependence on certain key personnel are analyzed and mitigated.
Costs associated with I&T resources (human, technical, suppliers) are known and tracked.
Governance decisions incorporate the search for a balance between costs, risks, and value.
Resource optimization initiatives (rationalization, mutualization, automation) are managed.
The lifecycle of I&T resources (acquisition, operation, renewal, retirement) is managed in a structured manner.
Decisions on resource renewal or retirement take into account criticality and risks.
Obsolete or redundant resources are identified and progressively eliminated.
The overall adequacy of I&T resources (quantity, quality, skills, technologies) is regularly reviewed by governance.
Feedback from business functions and I&T teams on resource constraints is taken into account.
Decisions made gradually improve the effectiveness and efficiency of resource usage.
Key I&T stakeholders (management, business functions, users, regulators, partners) are identified.
Their information expectations (frequency, level of detail, topics) are analyzed.
A stakeholder map with their information needs is available.
An I&T reporting model to stakeholders is defined (formats, channels, bodies).
This reporting model covers performance, risks, compliance, costs, and value.
Responsibilities for producing, consolidating, and validating reports are clear.
Regular dashboards on the performance of I&T services and projects are produced.
The indicators presented are understandable for non-technical stakeholders.
Significant deviations (performance degradation, failure to meet objectives) are explained and accompanied by action plans.
Major I&T risks and significant incidents are reported to the relevant governance bodies and stakeholders.
Information communicated on risks is balanced (transparency without unnecessary alarmism).
Decisions on risk treatment or acceptance are documented and communicated.
The results of audits, controls, and assessments (internal or external) concerning I&T are shared with the relevant stakeholders.
Action plans resulting from these assessments are communicated (at least to responsible parties and governance bodies).
The status of these action plans is integrated, when relevant, into regular reports.
Mechanisms for stakeholder feedback on the information provided exist (committees, surveys, bilateral exchanges).
Requests for changes to reports (content, frequency, format) are analyzed and addressed.
Modifications made to the reporting mechanism are communicated to stakeholders.
Specific communication arrangements are planned for crisis situations or major I&T incidents.
Messages addressed to stakeholders in case of an incident are coordinated and validated at the appropriate level.
Stakeholder feedback after a crisis is taken into account to improve future communication.
The overall effectiveness of I&T transparency and reporting is periodically evaluated (relevance, usefulness, comprehension).
Changes in stakeholder needs (new requirements, new regulators, new risks) are integrated into the framework.
Continuous improvement actions for I&T reporting and transparency are planned and monitored.
A program and project management methodology (lifecycle, phases, deliverables) is defined and formalised.
This methodology is aligned with the organisation's practices (PMO, portfolio, governance).
Project managers and stakeholders know the methodology and the main expected deliverables.
Each project has an approved charter or initiation document (objectives, scope, budget, deadlines).
Business sponsors formally validate the objectives and scope of I&T projects.
Project success criteria are defined from the start (expected benefits, indicators).
Detailed project plans exist (schedule, milestones, resources, budget).
Dependencies between projects and programs are identified and tracked.
Plans are updated based on progress and arbitration decisions.
Project risks and opportunities are formalised in a specific register.
Risk response plans (reduction, transfer, acceptance) are defined and tracked.
Quality control mechanisms are planned in projects (reviews, validations, tests).
Project progress (costs, deadlines, scope, risks) is monitored using reports or indicators.
Projects in difficulty are identified based on objective criteria (delays, budget overruns, quality).
Decisions (remedial plan, re-scoping, stop) are taken for projects in difficulty.
Scope changes are formalised and assessed (impact on costs, deadlines, risks).
Decisions on these changes are taken at the right level (project committee, sponsor, governance committee).
Project documents are updated to reflect approved changes.
Projects are formally closed (closing report, deliverable validation, assessment).
Lessons learned (REX - retour d'exprience) are carried out for significant projects.
Lessons learned from projects feed into the improvement of project management practices.
Programs (coherent sets of projects) are managed with a consolidated view of benefits, risks, and dependencies.
Portfolio decisions (prioritisation, launch, stop) take this consolidated view into account.
Governance bodies receive a global view on the status of major programs and projects.
A structured approach to requirements management (collection, analysis, validation) is defined.
Roles for requirements management (business, analysts, architects) are clearly identified.
Standardised models or templates are used to document requirements.
Business needs are gathered via appropriate techniques (workshops, interviews, observation, prototyping).
Needs are formalised in language understandable by both business and I&T.
Business stakeholders validate the expressed needs before their translation into detailed requirements.
Functional and non-functional requirements (performance, security, usability, etc.) are defined.
Requirements are analysed to detect inconsistencies, redundancies, or gaps.
Requirements are validated by business and I&T teams before the design or development phase.
Requirements are prioritised according to defined criteria (business value, risks, regulatory constraints).
Arbitration on priorities is done in consultation with the business.
Prioritisation decisions are traced and communicated to the relevant teams.
Traceability exists between requirements, use cases, specifications, tests, and deliverables.
Traceability matrices are used to verify coverage of needs.
Changes in requirements are reflected in the traceability elements.
Changes to requirements follow a formal process (request, impact analysis, decision).
The impacts of requirements changes on costs, deadlines, and risks are assessed.
Decisions on these changes are communicated to all concerned stakeholders.
Requirements take into account regulatory, security, and performance constraints.
Technical and architectural constraints (standards, enterprise architecture, integration) are incorporated from the definition of requirements.
Risks related to complex or ambiguous requirements are identified and tracked.
Before go-live, it is verified that priority requirements are covered by the delivered solution.
Business validates that their essential needs are properly addressed.
Any discrepancies between initial needs and the provided solution are documented and accepted.
A development or integration lifecycle (SDLC) is defined for I&T solutions.
This cycle includes at least the phases of design, build, test, deployment, and support.
Project teams systematically apply this lifecycle.
Solutions are designed consistently with enterprise architecture and technical standards.
Functional and technical designs are documented and reviewed.
Constraints related to performance, security, operations, and maintenance are integrated from the design phase.
Developments or configurations are carried out according to coding or configuration standards.
Code or configuration reviews are performed for critical components.
Development and integration environments are separated from production.
Unit and integration tests are carried out and tracked.
Detected defects are recorded, prioritised, and corrected.
Test exit criteria are defined (success rate, criticality of remaining anomalies).
Security requirements are taken into account in development (controls, encryption, logging).
Specific security tests or reviews are carried out for sensitive solutions.
Identified vulnerabilities are corrected before go-live where possible.
Test and pre-production environments are representative of production.
Data used in testing complies with confidentiality and data protection constraints.
Procedures for refreshing and managing environments are defined.
Interfaces and integrations with existing systems are formally specified and tested.
Impacts on existing applications and data are analysed.
Integration tests cover critical inter-system flows.
Documentation (technical, operational, administrative) of the solution is produced.
Deployment and rollback procedures are defined and tested.
Operations and support teams receive necessary information before go-live.
Availability objectives are defined for critical services and applications.
Capacity objectives (volumes, peak load, growth) are identified.
Business needs in terms of availability and performance are taken into account in these objectives.
Resource consumption (CPU, memory, storage, network) is monitored for key components.
Load and performance trends are regularly analysed.
Alerts and thresholds are defined to anticipate capacity saturation.
Availability and performance incidents are recorded and analysed.
Root causes of major downtimes are sought.
Improvement actions are defined and tracked to reduce these incidents.
A capacity plan is maintained, describing forecast demand evolution and envisaged responses.
Investment decisions (servers, licenses, storage, network) take this plan into account.
Revisions to the capacity plan are carried out at a defined frequency.
SLAs and performance objectives are used as a reference to assess availability and capacity.
Significant deviations from SLAs are analysed with the business.
Action plans are put in place to improve satisfaction related to availability and performance.
Load or performance tests are carried out for critical solutions.
The results of these tests are used to validate infrastructure sizing.
Load ramp-up scenarios are taken into account during new go-lives.
Continuity needs (RPO, RTO) are defined for key services.
Redundancy and recovery mechanisms are in place for critical components.
Recovery procedures are tested periodically.
Regular reviews of performance and availability are conducted with the business.
Identified improvements (optimisation, reconfiguration, redesign) are planned.
Availability and performance indicators show a controlled or improving trend.
An organisational change management approach is defined for I&T initiatives.
This approach describes communication, training, support, and resistance management activities.
Significant projects systematically include a change management component.
The impacts of projects on business processes, roles, and organisation are analysed.
A mapping of impacted populations is carried out (by profile, department, location).
Support needs are tailored according to these impacts.
Communication plans are defined for major changes (messages, channels, calendar).
Messages are clear on the objectives, benefits, impacts, and practical arrangements of the change.
User feedback on communication is taken into account (questions, misunderstandings, rumours).
Training plans are established for users impacted by the new systems or processes.
Training materials are adapted to the profiles (end-users, administrators, support).
Participation in training and comprehension of content are evaluated.
Managers of impacted teams are involved in change management.
They have the necessary information and tools to support their teams.
Managers relay key messages and facilitate the adoption of new practices.
Resistance to change is identified (via feedback, surveys, incidents).
Targeted actions are carried out to address resistance points (listening, support, adjustments).
Changes in user adoption are monitored over time.
Adoption of new solutions or processes is measured (usage, frequency, performance indicators).
User satisfaction is evaluated after major deployments.
Corrective actions are initiated if adoption or satisfaction is insufficient.
Lessons learned on change management are carried out for the main projects.
Best practices and mistakes to avoid are documented.
These lessons are reused in subsequent projects.
A formalised I&T change management process exists (creation, evaluation, approval, implementation, closure).
Types of changes are defined (standard, normal, urgent) with their own rules.
Teams are aware of this process and use it for their change requests.
Change requests are recorded in a dedicated tool or register.
Each request includes at a minimum: description, justification, scope, risks, implementation plan, and rollback plan.
Requests are categorised and prioritised.
Impacts of changes on services, infrastructures, security, and business are analysed.
High-risk changes are subject to in-depth analysis and more formal validation.
Potential conflicts between changes (windows, resources) are identified.
A Change Advisory Board (CAB) or equivalent reviews and approves significant changes.
Business is involved in decisions for changes that impact them.
Change committee decisions are documented.
Changes are planned within release windows compatible with business constraints.
Critical changes are coordinated with operations, network, security, etc. teams.
Change freeze periods are defined during sensitive times (peak activity, closings).
Implementation and rollback plans are known before the change execution.
The execution of changes is monitored and tracked (success, failure, related incidents).
Failed or problematic changes are subject to analysis and corrective measures.
Change records are linked to system documentation and the CMDB.
Operating documents and procedures are updated following changes.
Documentation updates are verified as part of the change process.
Change management indicators are tracked (success rate, urgent changes, post-change incidents).
The results of these indicators are examined to improve the process.
Change practices evolve to reduce incidents and increase the success rate.
Acceptance criteria are defined for deliverables before going into production.
These criteria are known by the project, business, and operations teams.
Deliverables are formally evaluated against these criteria before acceptance.
A testing strategy (functional, technical, non-regression) is defined for each project.
Test plans include representative business scenarios.
Test results are documented and used as the basis for acceptance decisions.
Migration strategies (data, users, processes) are defined before deployment.
Cut-over plans are detailed and tested when necessary.
Risks associated with migrations are identified and taken into account.
Go-lives follow formalised procedures (release management).
Production teams validate go-live plans before execution.
Go-live results are tracked (success, incidents, rollbacks).
Operational prerequisites (supervision, backups, security, procedures) are verified before go-live.
Operational and support responsibilities are assigned for new services.
Outsourcing services or external suppliers are involved if necessary before going live.
A structured handover is organised between project teams and run/support teams.
Support teams have the necessary documentation, access, and tools from the moment of go-live.
Knowledge transfer sessions are carried out if needed.
A warranty or hypercare period is planned after major go-lives.
Incidents and requests during this period are monitored in a reinforced manner.
Recurrent problems identified during the warranty period are subject to lasting corrections.
Business validates the conformity of delivered solutions against needs and acceptance criteria.
Projects are closed after confirmation that the transition to operations is stabilised.
Lessons learned from the transition phase are collected and shared.
A strategy or framework for I&T knowledge management is defined.
Types of knowledge to manage (technical, functional, procedures, lessons learned) are identified.
Knowledge management objectives (incident reduction, resolution times, quality) are clarified.
A central repository or tool (knowledge base, wiki, portal) is used to store I&T knowledge.
The structure of this repository is coherent and facilitates information retrieval.
Access rights are managed to protect sensitive information.
Lessons learned (major incidents, projects) lead to formal capitalisation.
Solutions to recurrent problems are documented in the knowledge base.
Teams are encouraged to share their knowledge (communities of practice, workshops).
System, process, and service documentation is centralised or referenced.
User guides, support procedures, FAQs are available for key services.
Documentation updates are integrated into project and change processes.
The content of the knowledge repository is effectively searchable (search engine, indexing).
Metadata (keywords, categories, date, author) are used to qualify the content.
Users can easily find the necessary information to resolve incidents or perform their tasks.
Knowledge owner roles are defined for key areas.
These owners ensure the quality, relevance, and updating of the content.
Contributions to the knowledge base are encouraged and recognized.
Regular reviews of content (obsolete, redundant, incomplete) are carried out.
Obsolete documents are archived or deleted.
Critical documents are reviewed according to a defined frequency.
Knowledge base usage is measured (consultations, resolution rate via the base).
Metrics show a contribution of knowledge management to the improvement of support and projects.
User feedback on the quality of knowledge is taken into account to improve the system.
An inventory of I&T assets (hardware, software, data, documentation) is maintained.
Each key asset has a unique identifier in the inventory.
The inventory is updated upon asset acquisition, change, or retirement.
Assets are classified by type, criticality, and business or I&T owner.
Management responsibilities for each asset category are defined.
Classification information is used for security, maintenance, and prioritization.
The asset lifecycle is managed (acquisition, deployment, operation, maintenance, retirement).
Renewal or retirement decisions take into account obsolescence and associated risks.
Retired assets are managed in accordance with security and compliance obligations (erasure, destruction).
Software licenses are inventoried with their terms and conditions (count, duration, scope).
Compliance with license agreements is verified periodically.
Risks of over-licensing or under-licensing are identified and addressed.
Physical assets are protected (secure premises, access controls, regular inventories).
Logical assets (data, software) are protected according to their sensitivity.
Loss, theft, or degradation of assets are subject to specific procedures.
Costs associated with assets (acquisition, maintenance, licenses) are tracked.
Investment or rationalization decisions are based on this information.
Underutilized or redundant assets are identified to optimize costs.
Risks related to assets (obsolescence, vulnerabilities, dependencies) are identified.
These risks are taken into account in the overall I&T risk management.
Action plans exist for high-risk assets.
Regular reconciliation is performed between the asset inventory, procurement, the CMDB, and technical tools.
Detected anomalies (undeclared assets, duplicates) are addressed.
The quality of the asset inventory is monitored using metrics.
A Configuration Management Database (CMDB) or equivalent tool is implemented.
A data model describes the types of Configuration Items (CIs) and their relationships.
Major services, applications, infrastructures, and components are represented in the CMDB.
Configuration Items are uniquely identified (naming convention, code, reference).
Relationships between items (dependencies, hosting, composition) are modeled.
Essential information (version, owner, location) is recorded for each CI.
The change management process mandates updating the CMDB during each validated change.
Deployments are an opportunity to verify and adjust Configuration Items.
Links between change requests, deployments, and affected CIs are tracked.
Procedures describe the creation, modification, and deletion of CIs in the CMDB.
Teams know when and how to update the CMDB.
Controls are performed to ensure the CMDB is updated after major changes.
CMDB data quality is evaluated (completeness, accuracy, consistency).
Audits or reconciliation (with inventory, monitoring tools, virtualization) are performed.
Identified discrepancies are corrected and analyzed to prevent their recurrence.
Access to the CMDB is controlled (profiles, read/write permissions).
Sensitive operations (mass modifications) are restricted and traced.
CMDB backups and recovery plans are in place.
The CMDB is used to analyze impacts during incidents or changes.
Configuration reports (maps, service views) support operational decisions.
Support teams use the CMDB to accelerate incident diagnosis.
The configuration management process is subject to regular reviews.
Identified improvements (automation, integration with other tools) are planned.
The maturity and utility of the CMDB progress over time.
A formal process for I&T operations management (exploitation) is defined and documented.
This process covers daily operational activities (monitoring, processing, backups, etc.).
Roles and responsibilities for I&T operations are clearly defined and known.
Recurring processing (batch, interfaces, scheduled tasks) are inventoried.
Launch schedules and dependencies between processing tasks are planned.
Processing failures are detected, recorded, and subject to corrective actions.
Technical supervision of systems (servers, databases, networks, applications) is in place.
Thresholds and alerts are defined to detect malfunctions or capacity saturation.
Alerts are handled according to defined procedures and deadlines.
A backup policy is defined (frequency, scope, retention) for systems and data.
Backups are automated, monitored, and failures are addressed.
Restoration tests are carried out periodically to verify data recoverability.
System and application logs are collected and retained according to defined rules.
Critical logs (security, access, sensitive operations) are protected against modifications.
Logs are used in case of incidents or investigations to reconstruct events.
Operating procedures (start/stop, monitoring, interventions) are documented for key systems.
Instructions are accessible to on-call and support teams.
Procedures are updated after significant technical changes.
Critical operational tasks are identified and, where possible, automated.
Human errors in operations (manipulations, scripts) are analyzed and lead to preventive actions.
The use of scheduling tools, supervision, and scripts is governed by best practices.
Operational metrics (availability, technical incidents, processing failures) are tracked.
Regular performance reviews of I&T operations are organized.
The results of these reviews feed into operational improvement plans.
A formal process for incident and service request management is defined.
Ticket types are clearly distinguished (incident, request, problem, change).
Teams use a single tool or register to record tickets.
A single point of contact (service desk, support center) is defined for users.
Contact channels (phone, portal, email, chat) are known to users.
Support hours and service levels are communicated.
Tickets are recorded with essential information (requester, description, impacted service, priority).
Priorities are defined according to impact/urgency criteria.
Tickets are categorized to allow for statistical analysis.
Procedures exist for functional and hierarchical escalation of incidents.
Major incidents follow a specific management process (crisis unit, reinforced communication).
Handling and resolution times are tracked against commitments (SLA).
Standard service requests (e.g., account creation, access, equipment) are defined and documented.
Simplified or automated workflows exist for these frequent requests.
Average processing times for standard requests are tracked.
Users are informed of the progress status of their incidents and requests (notifications, portal).
Communications during major incidents are coordinated with the business units.
A closing message is sent to users with a summary of the resolution.
Satisfaction surveys are offered to users upon the closure of certain tickets.
Satisfaction results are analyzed by service or request type.
Improvement actions are defined when satisfaction is insufficient.
Incident/request management metrics (volumes, SLA compliance, re-openings) are tracked.
Trends (increase, seasonality, distribution by service) are analyzed.
Ticket analyses contribute to the identification of recurring problems.
A formal problem management process, distinct from incident management, is formalized.
The roles of problem manager and analysis teams are identified.
Criteria for problem creation (recurrence, impact, severity) are defined.
Recurring or significant incidents are analyzed to determine if they should be grouped as problems.
Problems are recorded with a description, symptoms, and impacted services.
Links between incidents and associated problems are traced in the tool.
Root cause analyses are carried out for major problems (structured method).
Technical, organizational, or human causes are investigated.
The results of the analyses are documented and validated.
Permanent solutions (fixes, architectural changes, training) are defined to address the root causes of problems.
These solutions are planned and tracked via change requests or projects.
Problems are closed when solutions have been implemented and validated.
Workarounds are defined to reduce impact while awaiting the permanent solution.
These workarounds are documented in the knowledge base.
Support teams know and use these workarounds when relevant.
A Known Error Database is maintained.
Entries in this database include symptoms, causes, workarounds, and associated fixes.
The database is consulted when handling similar incidents.
Problem management metrics (number of open/closed problems, resolution time, avoided incidents) are tracked.
Results are shared with I&T management and, if necessary, with the business units.
Gains achieved (reduction of recurrence, increased stability) are documented.
Periodic reviews of major and recurring problems are organized.
Lessons learned from problems feed into the improvement of processes, architecture, or development practices.
Action plans resulting from these reviews are tracked until their implementation.
A policy or framework for I&T service continuity management is defined.
This framework is aligned with the organization's overall Business Continuity Management (BCM).
Roles and responsibilities for I&T continuity are formalized.
I&T services critical for business operations are identified and prioritized.
Continuity objectives (RTO, RPO) are defined for these critical services.
Dependencies (applications, infrastructures, suppliers) are documented for each critical service.
A Business Impact Analysis (BIA) has been performed for the main business processes.
BIA results are used to define I&T recovery priorities.
Required service levels in case of a degraded situation are known.
IT Continuity and Disaster Recovery Plans (DRP) exist for critical services.
These plans describe disaster scenarios, failover, and recovery procedures.
Contact details for key personnel and suppliers are included in the plans.
Continuity/recovery tests or exercises are organized periodically.
The results of these tests are documented (successes, difficulties, measured times).
Plans are updated following lessons learned from the exercises.
Critical suppliers and service providers have their own continuity arrangements.
Suppliers' continuity commitments (SLA/DRP) are known and integrated into the overall strategy.
Where possible, continuity tests involving suppliers are carried out.
I&T crisis management procedures are defined (activation, governance, communication).
Roles within the crisis unit are identified (decision-makers, communication, technical).
Major crisis scenarios (cyberattack, site loss, prolonged outage) are covered.
Periodic reviews of the I&T continuity strategy are organized.
Changes in the environment (new systems, new risks, organization) are taken into account.
Continuity plans are validated and approved by the appropriate governance bodies.
An operational security system (SOC, security team, service provider) is in place.
Roles and responsibilities for operating security services are defined.
Managed security services cover at least monitoring, detection, and incident response.
Technical security devices (firewalls, antivirus, EDR, proxies, etc.) are deployed across the defined scope.
Signatures, rules, and configurations of these devices are kept up to date.
Security configuration changes follow control procedures.
A vulnerability management process (scans, prioritization, remediation) is in place.
Significant vulnerabilities are analyzed based on their criticality and exposure.
Remediation plans are tracked until correction or mitigation.
Security events (alerts, logs, anomalies) are collected and correlated.
Detection rules are defined to identify suspicious behavior or attacks.
Significant security events are investigated.
A security incident management process is defined (detection, qualification, response, closure).
Security incidents are classified according to their severity and impact.
Major incidents follow a reinforced process (communication, crisis unit, notification to authorities if necessary).
Access rights to systems and applications are managed according to the principle of least privilege.
Privileged accounts are subject to specific controls (vault, traceability, regular reviews).
Periodic reviews of access rights are conducted with business owners.
Users are sensitized to security best practices (campaigns, e-learning, phishing tests).
Newcomers receive security awareness training upon onboarding.
Awareness messages are adapted to different user profiles.
Operational security metrics are tracked (incidents, open vulnerabilities, remediation time).
Results are reported to governance bodies and relevant business owners.
Lessons learned from incidents and vulnerabilities feed into the improvement of security services.
Automated or I&T-dependent business controls (e.g., application controls) are identified.
The objectives of these controls (integrity, completeness, compliance) are defined.
Business owners for these controls are designated.
The design of application controls is documented (rules, parameters, frequencies).
Controls are aligned with regulatory and internal compliance requirements.
Changes in business rules are reflected in application controls.
Automated controls are executed at a defined frequency (real-time, daily, periodic).
Control results (OK, anomalies) are tracked.
Exceptions or anomalies reported by the controls are analyzed and processed.
Manual controls dependent on I&T (extractions, reconciliations) are described and formalized.
Control documentation (files, reports, dashboards) is retained for a defined period.
Critical manual controls are supervised by an appropriate hierarchical level.
Reconciliations (accounting, operational, technical) are performed to ensure data integrity.
Discrepancies identified during reconciliations are analyzed and corrected.
Recurring causes of discrepancies lead to corrective actions on processes or systems.
Key controls supporting critical processes are identified and evaluated regularly.
Evaluations take into account control results, incidents, audits, and changes in processes.
Ineffective or redundant controls are improved or rationalized.
Internal or external auditors rely on the description of application and business controls.
Audit recommendations related to I&T controls are tracked.
Action plans resulting from audits are implemented and evaluated.
Changes in systems or processes lead to a revision of associated controls.
Business units are involved in validating the continued effectiveness of controls after changes.
The control mapping is kept up to date and used as a reference during compliance reviews.
A formal I&T performance management system is defined (process, responsibilities, review frequency).
The objectives of this system cover operational performance, value creation, and compliance.
Key stakeholders (management, business units, I&T) are aware of this system.
Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) are defined for the main I&T services.
Performance indicators for projects and programs (costs, deadlines, quality, benefits) are also defined.
Indicators are aligned with strategic business and I&T objectives.
Data sources used for the indicators (tools, reports, databases) are identified.
The quality of management data (reliability, completeness, freshness) is regularly evaluated.
Identified data quality gaps are subject to corrective actions.
I&T performance indicators are presented in dashboards distributed to the relevant stakeholders.
The frequency of dashboard production is adapted to decision needs (e.g., monthly, quarterly).
Dashboards are presented during formal committees (I&T committee, governance committee, steering committee).
Significant deviations from performance objectives (KPIs in red) are analyzed.
The causes of these deviations (technical, organizational, external) are investigated and documented.
Corrective or preventive actions are decided and tracked to address major deviations.
I&T performance indicators include customer/user satisfaction metrics where relevant.
Satisfaction results are compared to defined targets or standards.
Feedback from users or business units is taken into account to adjust services or priorities.
A consolidated view of I&T performance (services, projects, security, risks, costs) is available to management.
This consolidated view is used during strategic and budgetary arbitrations.
Decisions made (prioritization, resource reallocation) are tracked and linked to performance information.
The I&T performance management system (indicators, instances, supports) is reviewed periodically.
Obsolete indicators are removed, and new indicators are introduced if necessary.
Stakeholder information needs are considered to evolve the management system.
A specific I&T internal control framework (or one integrated into the overall internal control) is defined.
This framework specifies objectives, principles, responsibilities, and covered areas (I&T processes, security, continuity, etc.).
The I&T internal control framework is approved by management or appropriate governance bodies.
A mapping of I&T processes and associated main risks is available.
Existing control points (manual, automated) are identified for these processes.
Key controls are distinguished from secondary controls.
Controls related to access, changes, operations, and security are included in the I&T internal control system.
Controls cover prevention, detection, and correction of anomalies.
Controls are aligned with identified risks and compliance requirements.
Regular tests or evaluations of the effectiveness of I&T controls are carried out (self-assessments, second-level controls, audits).
Tests cover both the control design and their operating effectiveness.
Test results are documented and shared with the responsible parties.
Identified control dysfunctions (missing, ineffective, non-applied controls) are listed.
Deviations are classified according to their severity and potential impact.
Action plans are implemented to correct or improve insufficient controls.
Significant incidents (errors, potential frauds, major failures) are analyzed from an internal control perspective.
Causes related to control weaknesses are identified (non-existent procedure, non-compliance, lack of supervision).
Lessons learned from incidents lead to adjustments or reinforcement of controls.
Results from I&T internal control assessments are integrated into the organization's overall internal control system.
I&T internal control reports are communicated to the risk/audit committees and management.
Action plans related to I&T internal control are tracked in the same bodies as other internal control action plans.
The I&T internal control framework is updated based on changes in processes, systems, risks, and regulatory requirements.
Internal control approaches and tools (frameworks, checklists, GRC tools) are improved over time.
The overall maturity of I&T internal control is periodically evaluated and improvement objectives are set.
Applicable external requirements for I&T are identified (laws, regulations, standards, directives, customer or partner requirements).
These requirements are mapped by domain (data protection, security, regulated sector, finance, etc.).
Responsibilities for monitoring these requirements (legal, compliance, CISO, CIO) are defined.
The impact of external requirements on I&T processes, systems, and data is analyzed.
Obligations are translated into internal requirements (policies, procedures, controls).
Affected stakeholders are informed of the obligations that impact them.
Specific controls are in place to ensure compliance with external requirements (e.g., GDPR, SOX, sectoral rules).
Compliance controls are integrated into the I&T internal control system.
Responsibilities for implementing and supervising these controls are clearly defined.
Compliance reviews (self-assessments, controls by the compliance function or legal department) are carried out.
Reviews cover the main applicable texts and critical areas (personal data, security, finance, etc.).
Results of compliance reviews are documented and shared with the responsible parties.
External audits or inspections by authorities (regulators, statutory auditors, customers) are prepared and followed up.
Requests for information from auditors or authorities are processed within reasonable timeframes.
External audit or control reports are analyzed and discussed with internal stakeholders.
Identified non-compliances (internal or external) are listed and classified according to their severity.
Action plans with owners and deadlines are defined for each significant non-compliance.
Follow-up of these action plans is ensured until resolution or acceptance of the residual risk.
Regulatory or normative changes are monitored (legal watch, participation in professional groups, etc.).
Significant changes are analyzed to assess their impacts on I&T.
Compliance plans associated with these changes are defined and tracked.
Governance bodies (management committee, risk committee, I&T committee) receive a regular summary of the I&T compliance status.
Major non-compliance risks are integrated into the organization's overall risk mapping.
The I&T compliance strategy and priorities are adjusted based on feedback from these bodies.
